user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of irq:
```c
static int irq(void)
{
	int rc = 0;
	char *err_msg="";
	enum metal_log_level mll= metal_get_log_level();
	int i, tst_irq[2];

	/* Do not show LOG_ERROR or LOG_DEBUG for expected fail case */
	metal_set_log_level(METAL_LOG_CRITICAL);

	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		/* we only want to test the lib API, so create 'virtual' IRQs */
		tst_irq[i] = eventfd(0,0);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
			  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
	}

	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[1], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 1 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}

	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 after unregistering failed\n";
		goto out;
	}
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[1]);

out:
	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		close(tst_irq[i]);
	}
	metal_set_log_level(mll);
	if ((err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc))
		rc = -EINVAL;
	if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg);
	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function irq:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The macro itself does not call any functions from <string.h> and therefore does not by itself cause out-of-bounds string accesses. A violation could only arise if metal_fmt(fmt) or _metal.common.log_handler internally use unsafe string.h functions (for example, metal_fmt copying fmt into a fixed-size buffer with strcpy/strcat/memcpy without length checks — e.g. a 64-byte buffer and a longer fmt), which would then violate Rule 21.17.
